body:
Sorry for causing confusion 🙈  - did not make myself clear. It's only an implicit vs. explicit thing, some linters will tell you to skip the `(:each)` part, because it's the default behavior. That's all.
It's uncommon for me to see, so I suggested to make the `before(:each)` a `before`, but it does not have any impact on the code itself.

Plus: it's of course also totally fine if you leave it like this :v:

For the shared contexts: yes, @F3PiX is right, you could use them here. But since you're setup is super minimal, I don't see a real benefit in doing so. Would probably just make things harder to read.
body_html:
Sorry for causing confusion 🙈 - did not make myself clear. It's only an implicit vs. explicit thing, some linters will tell you to skip the (:each) part, because it's the default behavior. That's all.
It's uncommon for me to see, so I suggested to make the before(:each) a before, but it does not have any impact on the code itself.

Plus: it's of course also totally fine if you leave it like this ✌️

For the shared contexts: yes, @F3PiX is right, you could use them here. But since you're setup is super minimal, I don't see a real benefit in doing so. Would probably just make things harder to read.
body_text:
Sorry for causing confusion 🙈  - did not make myself clear. It's only an implicit vs. explicit thing, some linters will tell you to skip the (:each) part, because it's the default behavior. That's all.
It's uncommon for me to see, so I suggested to make the before(:each) a before, but it does not have any impact on the code itself.
Plus: it's of course also totally fine if you leave it like this ✌️
For the shared contexts: yes, @F3PiX is right, you could use them here. But since you're setup is super minimal, I don't see a real benefit in doing so. Would probably just make things harder to read.
